template.name: AWS_Dynamic Image Transformation for CloudFront
template.desc: Dynamic Image Transformation for Amazon CloudFront (formerly Serverless Image Handler) enables real-time image processing through the global content delivery network (CDN) of Amazon CloudFront. This AWS Solution helps you automatically optimize visual content delivery while significantly reducing operational costs and complexity. By dynamically transforming a single source image on-demand, it eliminates the need to store multiple versions of the same image, resulting in substantial storage savings. This solution also enhances the user experience through faster load times with improved caching, while providing robust security controls to protect against inappropriate content, including URL signing, request validation, and content moderation features.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, its crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

countermeasure.name: Apply strong encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Applying strong encryption to your API Service involves several key steps designed to protect data in transit and at rest, ensuring that sensitive information remains confidential and secure against unauthorized access or eavesdropping. Here's how to implement this countermeasure:

1. Choose a Strong Encryption Standard

  • Use TLS (Transport Layer Security) for encrypting data in transit. TLS 1.2 or higher is recommended as it offers strong cipher suites.
  • For data at rest, AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) with a key size of at least 256 bits is recommended for its balance of speed and security.

2. Implement TLS for All API Connections

  • Ensure all API endpoints are accessible only via HTTPS, not HTTP.
  • Acquire and install an SSL/TLS certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
  • Enforce HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) to prevent SSL stripping attacks.

3. Secure Your Encryption Keys

  • Use a secure key management system to store and handle encryption keys.
  • Rotate encryption keys periodically to limit the time window an attacker has to exploit a stolen key.
  • Ensure that keys are stored separately from the data they encrypt, preferably using hardware security modules (HSMs).

4. Use Secure Protocols and Algorithms

  • Regularly update your encryption algorithms and libraries to protect against vulnerabilities.
  • Avoid using deprecated protocols like SSLv3 and earlier versions of TLS (1.0 and 1.1).
  • Disable weak cipher suites that do not offer adequate security (e.g., those using less than 128-bit encryption).

5. Validate Client-Side Encryption

  • If client-side encryption is used, ensure that the data is encrypted before transmission and decrypted only after arriving at its destination.
  • Implement proper error handling to prevent leakage of sensitive information through client-side exceptions or logging.

6. Conduct Regular Security Audits

  • Regularly test your encryption implementation with penetration testing and vulnerability scanning to identify and remediate potential weaknesses.
  • Stay informed about the latest security advisories and updates for the encryption standards and libraries you use.

7. Ensure Compliance with Relevant Standards and Regulations

  • Be aware of and comply with any industry-specific regulations (such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS) that may mandate specific encryption standards or practices.

References to Good Security Practices

  • OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project) provides resources and guidelines for secure coding practices, including encryption.
  • NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) offers comprehensive guides on encryption standards and key management.

By following these steps, you will significantly enhance the security of your API Service through strong encryption, protecting sensitive data against interception and unauthorized access. Remember, encryption is just one aspect of a comprehensive security strategy, so it should be combined with other security measures for best results.

reference.name: API security
Encrypting Data-at-Rest and Data-in-Transit

countermeasure.name: Implement a proper authorization mechanism that relies on the user policies and hierarchy
countermeasure.desc:
To implement a proper authorization mechanism that relies on user policies and hierarchy, follow these steps:

Define User Roles and Permissions:

  • Start by defining clear user roles within your application, such as Administrator, Manager, and User. Each role should have permissions associated with it that define what actions each role can perform.
  • Use a principle of least privilege approach, meaning users should be granted the minimum permissions necessary to perform their job functions.

Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to manage permissions. With RBAC, you can assign roles to users and permissions to roles, making it easier to manage who can access what.
  • Ensure that access controls are enforced at all levels of your application, including the frontend and backend.

Use Access Control Lists (ACLs) for Fine-Grained Control:

  • For more granular control, use Access Control Lists (ACLs) alongside RBAC. ACLs allow you to specify detailed permissions for individual users or roles on specific resources.
  • This is useful for scenarios where roles need to be more dynamic or when permissions need to be tightly controlled.

Incorporate User Hierarchy into Permissions:

  • Design your authorization model to reflect your organizations hierarchy. This means if a user has a certain level of access, they can delegate subsets of their access to users below them in the hierarchy.
  • Implement checks to ensure users can only access data or perform actions that are appropriate for their level in the hierarchy.

Securely Manage Authentication Tokens:

  • Use secure, short-lived authentication tokens (such as JWTs) to manage user sessions. Ensure tokens are securely stored and transmitted using HTTPS.
  • Implement token expiration and renewal policies to limit the duration of an active session.

Regularly Review and Update Permissions:

  • Periodically review user roles and permissions to ensure they are still in alignment with job functions and organizational policies.
  • Automate the process of revoking access for users who no longer need it, such as when they change roles or leave the organization.

Test and Audit:

  • Regularly test your authorization mechanisms to ensure they are secure and functioning as expected. Use automated tools where possible.
  • Implement logging and auditing capabilities to monitor access and changes to permissions. This can help detect unauthorized access attempts and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

Stay Updated with Best Practices:

  • Stay informed about the latest security best practices and update your authorization mechanisms as needed. Engaging with security communities and attending workshops can be beneficial.

Document Your Authorization Model:

  • Document your authorization model and make the documentation available to your development team. This ensures everyone understands the access control mechanisms in place and how to implement new features securely.

By following these steps, you can implement a robust authorization mechanism that securely manages access based on user policies and hierarchy, enhancing the overall security posture of your API service.

countermeasure.name: Implement best practices for API authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing best practices for API authentication is crucial for securing your API Service against unauthorized access and ensuring that only legitimate users and services can interact with your system. Here's how you can implement these practices:

1. Use Standard Authentication Protocols

  • Implement OAuth 2.0: For most web-based applications, OAuth 2.0 is the industry-standard protocol for authorization. It provides specific authorization flows for web applications, desktop applications, mobile phones, and living room devices.
  • Use OpenID Connect for scenarios requiring identity verification. It's built atop OAuth 2.0 and adds an authentication layer, ensuring that the user is who they claim to be.

2. Secure Your API Keys

  • Limit API Key Access: Assign API keys to individual users or services with the minimal necessary permissions to perform their tasks.
  • Rotate and expire API keys periodically to minimize the impact of compromised keys.
  • Monitor API key usage to detect potential abuse or unauthorized access patterns.

3. Employ Access Tokens

  • Use JWT (JSON Web Tokens) for access tokens where possible. JWTs can securely convey information between parties as a JSON object, allowing for stateless authentication.
  • Implement token expiration: Access tokens should have a short expiration time, while refresh tokens can have a longer lifespan. This limits the damage in case an access token is compromised.

4. Implement Rate Limiting

  • Throttle API requests to prevent abuse and to mitigate brute-force attacks. Rate limiting can be based on the number of requests per time window and can vary for different types of users or IP addresses.

5. Use HTTPS

  • Ensure all API requests are sent over HTTPS to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks. Never allow unencrypted API communications.

6. Validate Input to Prevent Injection Attacks

  • Validate and sanitize all user input to prevent SQL injection, XML injection, and other injection attacks. Use parameterized queries and avoid direct execution of user-supplied data.

7. Consider Using Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for Sensitive Operations

  • For highly sensitive or critical operations, consider adding an extra layer of security by requiring MFA, ensuring that users provide two or more verification factors to gain access.

8. Regularly Review and Update Authentication Mechanisms

  • Security threats evolve, so regularly review your API authentication methods for any vulnerabilities and update them as needed. Stay informed about the latest security practices and update your protocols accordingly.

9. Educate Your Users and Developers

  • Provide guidance on secure usage of your API, including the safe handling of API keys and credentials. Educate developers about securing their applications and maintaining the confidentiality of authentication credentials.

References to Good Security Practices

  • OWASP API Security Top 10: A list of the most critical security risks to web applications, including authentication flaws.
  • NIST Digital Identity Guidelines: Provides comprehensive guidelines on digital identity management, including authentication practices.

By implementing these best practices for API authentication, you can significantly reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that your API remains secure, reliable, and trustworthy.

reference.name: How to Secure APIs
OWASP REST Security Cheat Sheet
OWASP Testing Guide v4. Testing for authentication

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive logging and SIEM integration
countermeasure.desc:
In order to fortify the security posture of our API Service, it is imperative to implement a robust logging mechanism and seamlessly integrate it with a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system. This control ensures that all relevant activities and events within the API ecosystem are recorded, monitored, and analyzed in real-time, enhancing our ability to detect and respond to security incidents promptly.

Implementation Guidelines:

Granular Logging:

  • Implement detailed and granular logging mechanisms to capture pertinent information about API requests, responses, user authentication, and authorization events.
  • Log relevant metadata such as timestamps, source IP addresses, user identities, and the nature of the API transactions.

Sensitive Data Masking:

  • Apply appropriate data masking techniques to prevent the logging of sensitive information such as passwords, personal identifiable information (PII), and other confidential data.

Logging Standards:

  • Adhere to industry-standard logging formats (e.g., JSON, syslog) to ensure compatibility with SIEM solutions and facilitate efficient log parsing and analysis.

Log Retention and Rotation:

  • Define a log retention policy to ensure logs are retained for an appropriate duration based on compliance requirements and security best practices.
  • Implement log rotation to prevent storage overflow and maintain a manageable log volume.

Real-time Alerting:

  • Integrate the logging system with a SIEM solution to enable real-time monitoring and alerting on suspicious or anomalous activities.
  • Configure alerts for specific events that may indicate security incidents, such as multiple failed login attempts or unusual patterns of API access.

Access Controls for Logs:

  • Implement access controls and encryption for log files to restrict access only to authorized personnel.
  • Regularly review and audit access to log files to ensure compliance and detect unauthorized access.

Integration with Incident Response:

  • Ensure that the logging system is seamlessly integrated with the organization's incident response processes and tools.
  • Define clear procedures for incident identification, analysis, and response based on the information gathered from the logs.

Regular Monitoring and Review:

  • Periodically review and analyze logs to identify trends, potential security threats, or areas for improvement in the API service's security posture.
  • Conduct regular audits of the logging and SIEM integration to validate the effectiveness of the control.

Benefits:

  • Early detection of security incidents.
  • Improved forensic capabilities for investigating security breaches.
  • Compliance with regulatory requirements regarding data protection and incident reporting.
  • Enhanced visibility into API activities for both security and operational purposes.

Note to Developers: Implementing comprehensive logging and SIEM integration is not just a security requirement but a crucial aspect of maintaining the integrity and reliability of our API Service. Follow the guidelines diligently and collaborate with the security team to ensure the effective implementation of this control.

Recommendations for monitoring and threat detection

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and input validation
countermeasure.desc:
This security control is designed to bolster the resilience of our API Service against common vulnerabilities such as SQL injection and input-based attacks. By enforcing the use of parameterized queries and robust input validation, we aim to ensure that all user inputs are thoroughly scrutinized and processed securely, mitigating the risk of malicious exploitation.

Implementation Guidelines:

Parameterized Queries:

  • Utilize parameterized queries or prepared statements when interacting with databases to ensure that user inputs are treated as data rather than executable code.
  • Refrain from dynamically constructing SQL queries by concatenating user inputs directly into the query string.

Input Validation:

  • Implement strict input validation mechanisms to check the format, length, and type of incoming data.
  • Enforce whitelist validation for known and expected input values, rejecting anything that deviates from the defined criteria.

Regular Expression Checks:

  • Use regular expressions to validate inputs against predefined patterns, ensuring that data adheres to the expected format.
  • Employ regex patterns for common data types such as email addresses, phone numbers, and credit card numbers.

Sanitization of User Inputs:

  • Apply input sanitization techniques to remove or escape potentially harmful characters from user inputs.
  • Implement input filters to strip out or neutralize characters that could be used in injection attacks.

Validation at Multiple Layers:

  • Conduct input validation at multiple layers of the application stack, including client-side validation and server-side validation.
  • Do not solely rely on client-side validation, as it can be bypassed by malicious actors.

Error Handling:

  • Implement secure error handling mechanisms to provide minimal information in error messages, avoiding the disclosure of sensitive details that could aid attackers.
  • Log detailed error messages internally for debugging purposes, without exposing them to end-users.

Security Awareness Training:

  • Educate developers on the importance of input validation and secure coding practices through regular security awareness training.
  • Foster a culture of code review to ensure that input validation practices are consistently followed in the development process.

Benefits:

  • Mitigation of SQL injection and other injection-based attacks.
  • Prevention of data manipulation and unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Protection against common security vulnerabilities associated with user input.
  • Enhanced reliability and stability of the API Service.

Note to Developers: The implementation of parameterized queries and input validation is pivotal for safeguarding our API Service from a multitude of potential security threats. Adhere to these guidelines meticulously, integrate them into your coding practices, and collaborate with the security team to continuously assess and improve the security posture of the API Service.

countermeasure.name: Use rate limiting and throttling
countermeasure.desc:
To implement rate limiting and throttling as a security countermeasure for your API service, follow these actionable steps designed to guide developers, even those without previous security experience:

Understand Rate Limiting and Throttling:

  • Rate limiting controls how many requests a user or IP address can make to your API within a specified time frame, while throttling is the actual enforcement mechanism that slows down or blocks requests once the limit is exceeded.

Choose a Rate Limiting Strategy:

  • Decide on a rate limiting strategy based on your API's specific needs. Common strategies include:
    • Fixed Window Counting: Limits requests in a fixed time window (e.g., 100 requests per hour).
    • Sliding Log Algorithm: More flexible, using a moving time window to track requests.
    • Token Bucket Algorithm: Allows for burst traffic by using tokens that refill over time.
  • Consider using a combination of strategies for different endpoints based on their sensitivity and expected traffic patterns.

Implement Rate Limiting on the Server-Side:

  • Use middleware in your web server framework (e.g., Express.js for Node.js, Django middleware for Python) that supports rate limiting. Configure it according to your chosen strategy.
  • Set limits based on user authentication (if users are logged in) or IP addresses for anonymous access. Ensure limits are reasonable to prevent legitimate use from being affected while still protecting against abuse.

Store Request Counters and Timestamps:

  • Use a fast, in-memory data store like Redis to keep track of request counts and timestamps for each user or IP address. This enables quick checks and updates to rate limiting counters.

Apply Throttling Mechanisms:

  • Once a user hits the rate limit, apply throttling by either sending a 429 Too Many Requests HTTP status code with a message indicating when they can try again or by intentionally slowing down the response times for their requests.

Provide Feedback to Clients:

  • Include headers in responses that inform the client of their current rate limit status, such as X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, and X-RateLimit-Reset. This transparency helps clients understand their limits and adjust their request patterns.

Configure Sensible Defaults and Allow Overrides:

  • Set sensible default limits but allow for overrides on a per-route or per-user basis as needed. This flexibility can accommodate special cases or premium users requiring higher limits.

Monitor and Adjust Limits:

  • Regularly monitor your API's usage patterns and adjust rate limits as necessary. Be prepared to dynamically adjust limits in response to observed abuse or unexpected legitimate usage patterns.

Educate Your Users:

  • Document your rate limiting policies and make this information available to your API users. Clear communication helps prevent confusion and frustration.

Automate Responses to Abuse:

  • Implement automated systems to detect and respond to abusive behavior patterns. Consider temporary blocks or requiring additional authentication beyond a certain threshold of suspicious activity.

By incorporating rate limiting and throttling into your API service, you not only protect your infrastructure from abuse and overload but also ensure a fair and reliable service for all users. This proactive approach to API security helps maintain service availability and performance while safeguarding against malicious activities.

reference.name: NIST 800-53
OSA SC-05 Denial Of Service Protection
What Is the Difference Between API Rate Limiting and Throttle Controls?
What is rate limiting? | Rate limiting and bots

countermeasure.name: Validate input and implement allowlists
countermeasure.desc:
This security control emphasizes the importance of validating input data and enforcing allowlists to fortify the defenses of our API Service against a range of security threats. By thoroughly validating and allowing only trusted inputs, we aim to mitigate the risks associated with injection attacks, unauthorized access, and data manipulation.

Implementation Guidelines:

Input Validation:

  • Implement rigorous input validation procedures to verify the integrity and appropriateness of incoming data.
  • Enforce checks on data types, length, and format to ensure that inputs conform to expected standards.

Allowlisting:

  • Develop and maintain explicit allowlists that enumerate acceptable values and inputs for various parameters.
  • Reject any inputs that do not match the predefined allowlists, thereby reducing the attack surface for potential vulnerabilities.

Context-Specific Validation:

  • Tailor input validation based on the context in which the data is used. Different parts of the application may have distinct requirements for input validation.
  • Adjust validation criteria based on the sensitivity and criticality of the data being processed.

Regular Expression Validation:

  • Utilize regular expressions to validate and enforce specific patterns for inputs, especially for data types like email addresses, phone numbers, and other standardized formats.
  • Regular expression validation adds an additional layer of scrutiny to ensure data integrity.

Validation at Input Sources:

  • Perform input validation at the earliest possible point in the application workflow, preferably at the input sources.
  • Validate inputs on both the client-side and server-side to provide defense in depth against malicious input.

Dynamic Allowlist Management:

  • Implement dynamic allowlist management mechanisms to accommodate changes in application requirements and business logic.
  • Regularly review and update allowlists based on evolving security and application needs.

Security Testing:

  • Integrate automated security testing tools and methodologies into the development lifecycle to identify potential input validation vulnerabilities.
  • Conduct thorough penetration testing to assess the resilience of the application against various input-based attacks.

Benefits:

  • Reduction of attack surface by allowing only trusted inputs.
  • Prevention of injection attacks, including SQL injection and Cross-Site Scripting (XSS).
  • Mitigation of security risks associated with unauthorized access and data manipulation.
  • Improved overall security posture and resilience against input-based vulnerabilities.

Note to Developers: Implementing input validation and allowlisting is a proactive measure that significantly contributes to the security robustness of our API Service. Follow these guidelines diligently, collaborate with the security team, and integrate these practices into your development workflows to ensure the ongoing protection of our application against potential threats.

reference.name: OWASP Input Validation Cheat Sheet
OWASP Top 10 Proactive Controls - C5: Validate All Inputs

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Over consumption of the resources of the API server can render it inaccessible
threat.desc:
Satisfying API requests requires resources such as network bandwidth, CPU, memory, and storage. Other resources such as emails/SMS/phone calls or biometrics validation are made available by service providers via API integrations, and paid for per request. Successful attacks can lead to Denial of Service or an increase of operational costs.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

Exploitation requires simple API requests. Multiple concurrent requests can be performed from a single local computer or by using cloud computing resources. Most of the automated tools available are designed to cause DoS via high loads of traffic, impacting APIs service rate.

Impacts

Exploitation can lead to DoS due to resource starvation, but it can also lead to operational costs increase such as those related to the infrastructure due to higher CPU demand, increasing cloud storage needs, etc.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario #1

A social network implemented a forgot password flow using SMS verification, enabling the user to receive a one time token via SMS in order to reset their password.

Once a user clicks on "forgot password" an API call is sent from the user's browser to the back-end API:

POST /initiate_forgot_password {  "step": 1,  "user_number": "6501113434" }

Then, behind the scenes, an API call is sent from the back-end to a 3rd party API that takes care of the SMS delivering:

POST /sms/send_reset_pass_code Host: willyo.net {  "phone_number": "6501113434" }

The 3rd party provider, Willyo, charges $0.05 per this type of call.

An attacker writes a script that sends the first API call tens of thousands of times. The back-end follows and requests Willyo to send tens of thousands of text messages, leading the company to lose thousands of dollars in a matter of minutes.

Scenario #2

A GraphQL API Endpoint allows the user to upload a profile picture.

POST /graphql {  "query": "mutation {    uploadPic(name: \"pic1\", base64_pic: \"R0FOIEFOR0xJVA\") {      url    }  }" }

Once the upload is complete, the API generates multiple thumbnails with different sizes based on the uploaded picture. This graphical operation takes a lot of memory from the server.

The API implements a traditional rate limiting protection - a user can't access the GraphQL endpoint too many times in a short period of time. The API also checks for the uploaded picture's size before generating thumbnails to avoid processing pictures that are too large.

An attacker can easily bypass those mechanisms, by leveraging the flexible nature of GraphQL:

POST /graphql [  {"query": "mutation {uploadPic(name: \"pic1\", base64_pic: \"R0FOIEFOR0xJVA\") {url}}"},  {"query": "mutation {uploadPic(name: \"pic2\", base64_pic: \"R0FOIEFOR0xJVA\") {url}}"},  ...  {"query": "mutation {uploadPic(name: \"pic999\", base64_pic: \"R0FOIEFOR0xJVA\") {url}}"}, }

Because the API does not limit the number of times the uploadPic operation can be attempted, the call will lead to exhaustion of server memory and Denial of Service.

Scenario #3

A service provider allows clients to download arbitrarily large files using its API. These files are stored in cloud object storage and they don't change that often. The service provider relies on a cache service to have a better service rate and to keep bandwidth consumption low. The cache service only caches files up to 15GB.

When one of the files gets updated, its size increases to 18GB. All service clients immediately start pulling the new version. Because there were no consumption cost alerts, nor a maximum cost allowance for the cloud service, the next monthly bill increases from US$13, on average, to US$8k.

reference.name: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling
CWE-799: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency
Denial of Service
What Is a DDoS Attack?

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of weaknesses in access controls
threat.desc:
Improper access controls can lead to unauthorized access to data and functionality, allowing attackers to view, modify, or delete sensitive information. It may result in a compromise of the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of critical assets.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

Attackers can exploit API endpoints that are vulnerable to broken object-level authorization by manipulating the ID of an object that is sent within the request. Object IDs can be anything from sequential integers, UUIDs, or generic strings. Regardless of the data type, they are easy to identify in the request target (path or query string parameters), request headers, or even as part of the request payload.

This issue is extremely common in API-based applications because the server component usually does not fully track the clients state, and instead, relies more on parameters like object IDs, that are sent from the client to decide which objects to access. The server response is usually enough to understand whether the request was successful.

Impacts

Unauthorized access to other users objects can result in data disclosure to unauthorized parties, data loss, or data manipulation. Under certain circumstances, unauthorized access to objects can also lead to full account takeover.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario #1

An e-commerce platform for online stores (shops) provides a listing page with the revenue charts for their hosted shops. Inspecting the browser requests, an attacker can identify the API endpoints used as a data source for those charts and their pattern: /shops/{shopName}/revenue_data.json. Using another API endpoint, the attacker can get the list of all hosted shop names. With a simple script to manipulate the names in the list, replacing {shopName} in the URL, the attacker gains access to the sales data of thousands of e-commerce stores.

Scenario #2

An automobile manufacturer has enabled remote control of its vehicles via a mobile API for communication with the driver's mobile phone. The API enables the driver to remotely start and stop the engine and lock and unlock the doors. As part of this flow, the user sends the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) to the API. The API fails to validate that the VIN represents a vehicle that belongs to the logged in user, which leads to a BOLA vulnerability. An attacker can access vehicles that don't belong to him.

Scenario #3

An online document storage service allows users to view, edit, store and delete their documents. When a user's document is deleted, a GraphQL mutation with the document ID is sent to the API.

POST /graphql {  "operationName":"deleteReports",  "variables":{    "reportKeys":["<DOCUMENT_ID>"]  },  "query":"mutation deleteReports($siteId: ID!, $reportKeys: [String]!) {    {      deleteReports(reportKeys: $reportKeys)    }  }" }

Since the document with the given ID is deleted without any further permission checks, a user may be able to delete another user's document.

reference.name: Access control vulnerabilities and privilege escalation
Broken Access Control
CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
OWASP API1:2023 Broken Object Level Authorization

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers expose sensitive data
threat.desc:
Attackers exploit vulnerabilities in an organization's security defenses to gain unauthorized access and expose sensitive data. This threat involves the intentional revelation or theft of confidential or private information, posing serious risks to individuals and the organization.

Threat agents/Attack vectors:

Threat Agents:

  • External hackers
  • Insiders with malicious intent
  • Advanced persistent threats (APTs)
  • Cybercriminal groups

Attack Vectors:

  • Exploiting software vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access
  • Conducting phishing attacks to trick users into revealing sensitive information
  • Brute force attacks on weak authentication mechanisms
  • Exploiting misconfigurations in systems and databases

Impacts:

Data Breach:

  • Unauthorized exposure of sensitive information, such as personal, financial, or proprietary data, leading to potential legal and financial consequences.

Reputation Damage:

  • Loss of trust and credibility among customers, partners, and stakeholders due to the perceived inability to safeguard sensitive data.

Regulatory Compliance Violations:

  • Non-compliance with data protection regulations, leading to legal repercussions and financial penalties.

Identity Theft and Fraud:

  • Exposed personal information may be used for identity theft or fraudulent activities, causing harm to individuals.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Exploiting Unpatched Systems:

  • Attackers target systems with known vulnerabilities that have not been patched, gaining unauthorized access to databases containing sensitive information.

Phishing Attacks:

  • Using deceptive emails or messages, attackers trick employees into divulging sensitive information like login credentials, providing a gateway for unauthorized access.

Weak Authentication:

  • Brute force attacks against weak passwords or compromised credentials to gain access to systems containing sensitive data.

Database Misconfigurations:

  • Exploiting misconfigurations in databases or cloud storage systems, allowing attackers to access and expose sensitive information stored within.

Insider Threats:

  • Malicious insiders intentionally leak sensitive data or compromise security measures to enable external attackers to access and expose critical information.

reference.name: API3:2019 Excessive Data Exposure

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0010 - Exfiltration||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1087 - Account Discovery||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565 - Data Manipulation||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1213 - Data from Information Repositories||ATT&CK Mobile - T1409 - Stored Application Data

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Attackers go undetected by exploiting insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
Attackers exploit insufficient logging and monitoring to remain undetected during their activities. This threat involves the manipulation of gaps in an organization's logging and monitoring capabilities, allowing malicious actors to operate covertly and avoid detection.

Threat agents/Attack vectors:

Threat Agents:

  • Malicious insiders
  • External hackers
  • Advanced persistent threats (APTs)

Attack Vectors:

  • Exploiting vulnerabilities in logging mechanisms
  • Manipulating log entries
  • Evading detection by selectively avoiding monitored systems
  • Using encrypted communication channels to conceal activities

Impacts:

Undetected Intrusions:

  • Attackers can infiltrate systems without triggering alarms or alerts.
  • Persistent unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.

Delayed Incident Response:

  • Lack of timely detection prolongs the time it takes to respond to security incidents.
  • Increased damage and compromise as a result of delayed intervention.

Data Exfiltration:

  • Attackers can exfiltrate sensitive data without being noticed, leading to data breaches.

Reconnaissance and Intelligence Gathering:

  • Attackers can conduct extensive reconnaissance without raising suspicion, enabling more targeted and devastating attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Exploiting Log Deletion Gaps:

  • Attackers identify and exploit gaps in log retention policies, ensuring their activities are not recorded for an extended period, making it difficult for security teams to trace their actions.

Log Tampering:

  • Malicious insiders manipulate log entries to remove traces of their unauthorized access or actions, thereby avoiding detection by security monitoring systems.

Selective Targeting of Unmonitored Systems:

  • Attackers target systems that are not adequately monitored, exploiting blind spots in the organization's security infrastructure to conduct malicious activities without triggering alerts.

Encrypted Communication Channels:

  • Utilizing encrypted communication channels, attackers mask their activities from network monitoring tools, allowing them to exchange information, execute commands, and exfiltrate data without being detected.

reference.name: A09:2021 Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
Coders Conquer Security OWASP Top 10 API Series - Insufficient Logging and Monitoring

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain control of users' accounts in the system by abusing poorly implemented API authentication
threat.desc:
Authentication mechanisms are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise authentication tokens or to exploit implementation flaws to assume other user's identities temporarily or permanently. Compromising a system's ability to identify the client/user, compromises API security overall.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

The authentication mechanism is an easy target for attackers since it's exposed to everyone. Although more advanced technical skills may be required to exploit some authentication issues, exploitation tools are generally available.

Impacts

Attackers can gain complete control of other users accounts in the system, read their personal data, and perform sensitive actions on their behalf. Systems are unlikely to be able to distinguish attackers actions from legitimate user ones.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario #1

In order to perform user authentication the client has to issue an API request like the one below with the user credentials:

POST /graphql {  "query":"mutation {    login (username:\"<username>\",password:\"<password>\") {      token    }   }" }

If credentials are valid, then an auth token is returned which should be provided in subsequent requests to identify the user. Login attempts are subject to restrictive rate limiting: only three requests are allowed per minute.

To brute force log in with a victim's account, bad actors leverage GraphQL query batching to bypass the request rate limiting, speeding up the attack:

POST /graphql [  {"query":"mutation{login(username:\"victim\",password:\"password\"){token}}"},  {"query":"mutation{login(username:\"victim\",password:\"123456\"){token}}"},  {"query":"mutation{login(username:\"victim\",password:\"qwerty\"){token}}"},  ...  {"query":"mutation{login(username:\"victim\",password:\"123\"){token}}"}, ]

Scenario #2

In order to update the email address associated with a user's account, clients should issue an API request like the one below:

PUT /account Authorization: Bearer <token> { "email": "<new_email_address>" }

Because the API does not require users to confirm their identity by providing their current password, bad actors able to put themselves in a position to steal the auth token might be able to take over the victim's account by starting the reset password workflow after updating the email address of the victim's account.

reference.name: CAPEC-114: Authentication Abuse
CAPEC-57: Utilizing REST's Trust in the System Resource to Obtain Sensitive Data
OWASP API2:2023 Broken Authentication

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1003 - OS Credential Dumping||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0006 - Credential Access||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0001 - Initial Access||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1110 - Brute Force

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers compromise the system through inadequate input validation
threat.desc:
Attackers exploit inadequate input validation mechanisms within a system, allowing them to manipulate and inject malicious input. This threat involves the unauthorized compromise of the system's integrity, potentially leading to various security vulnerabilities and risks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors:

Threat Agents:

  • External hackers
  • Automated bots
  • Insiders with malicious intent

Attack Vectors:

  • Injection attacks (e.g., SQL injection, command injection)
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
  • Buffer overflow attacks
  • File upload vulnerabilities

Impacts:

Unauthorized Access:

  • Attackers may gain unauthorized access to sensitive areas of the system by injecting malicious input, bypassing authentication, and escalating privileges.

Data Manipulation:

  • Inadequate input validation can lead to manipulation of data stored within the system, resulting in data integrity compromises.

Code Execution:

  • Injection attacks, such as SQL injection or command injection, can lead to the execution of arbitrary code on the system, posing a severe security risk.

Denial of Service (DoS):

  • Attackers may leverage input validation vulnerabilities to launch DoS attacks, causing system instability or unavailability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

SQL Injection:

  • Attackers inject malicious SQL queries into input fields, exploiting inadequate input validation to manipulate databases and extract sensitive information.

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS):

  • Malicious actors inject scripts into web applications, taking advantage of insufficient input validation to execute scripts in users' browsers, leading to session hijacking or defacement.

Buffer Overflow Attacks:

  • Exploiting insufficient input validation, attackers may overflow input buffers with malicious data, potentially leading to the execution of arbitrary code on the system.

File Upload Vulnerabilities:

  • Attackers upload malicious files by bypassing inadequate input validation in file upload functionality, leading to potential remote code execution or unauthorized access.

Command Injection:

  • Exploiting input validation weaknesses, attackers inject malicious commands into system commands, potentially gaining unauthorized access or executing arbitrary actions.

reference.name: Input Validation Attacks
What is SQL Injection (SQLi) and How to Prevent It

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0002 - Execution||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1659 - Content Injection||ATT&CK Mobile - T1516 - Input Injection

threat.name: Attackers manipulate SSRF weaknesses to compromise the system
threat.desc:
Attackers exploit Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerabilities within a system, manipulating the server to make unintended requests to internal resources. This threat involves using SSRF to gain unauthorized access, retrieve sensitive information, or perform actions that compromise the system's security.

Threat agents/Attack vectors:

Threat Agents:

  • External hackers
  • Insiders with malicious intent

Attack Vectors:

  • Exploiting SSRF vulnerabilities in web applications or services
  • Forging requests to internal services, exploiting the trust relationships between components
  • Leveraging SSRF to perform reconnaissance on internal networks

Impacts:

Unauthorized Data Access:

  • Attackers may use SSRF to make requests to internal services or databases, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Internal Network Reconnaissance:

  • Exploiting SSRF, attackers can probe internal networks, identifying potential targets for further exploitation.

Service and Infrastructure Compromise:

  • SSRF can be leveraged to make requests to internal infrastructure components, leading to service disruption or compromise.

Abuse of Trusted Relationships:

  • Attackers exploit the trust between different components within a system, using SSRF to make unauthorized requests to internal resources.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Accessing Internal APIs:

  • Attackers exploit SSRF vulnerabilities to make requests to internal APIs, gaining access to sensitive information or functionality.

Bypassing Firewall Restrictions:

  • SSRF can be used to make requests to internal services that are not directly accessible from the external network, bypassing firewall restrictions.

Cloud Metadata Abuse:

  • In cloud environments, attackers leverage SSRF to access and abuse cloud metadata services, obtaining sensitive information about the hosting environment.

Exploiting Blind SSRF:

  • Attackers use SSRF to make requests to internal services without directly receiving the responses, utilizing techniques like out-of-band (OOB) SSRF to exfiltrate information.

reference.name: OWASP - Server Side Request Forgery
Server-side request forgery (SSRF)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-695
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-695: Use of Low-Level Functionality The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms, introduce exploitable inconsistencies, or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Activate deletion protection for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Enable deletion protection on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to prevent accidental or unauthorized removal of the load balancer. This setting adds an additional layer of security by ensuring that critical load balancer configurations cannot be deleted without explicit authorization. Activating deletion protection helps safeguard against human error, malicious actions, and potential service disruptions. Regularly review the status of deletion protection to confirm it remains enabled, ensuring continuous protection of your ALB and the applications it supports.

reference.name: Application Load Balancers

countermeasure.name: Configure strictest desync mitigation mode for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Set your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to operate using the strictest desynchronization (desync) mitigation mode available. This configuration helps defend against HTTP request smuggling and other desynchronization attacks that can exploit differences in how HTTP requests are processed between clients and servers. By enabling the strictest desync mitigation mode, you ensure that the ALB consistently handles incoming traffic in a secure manner, reducing the risk of these attacks and maintaining the integrity of data transmission. Regularly review and update this setting to align with best practices and evolving security threats.

reference.name: Application Load Balancers

countermeasure.name: Deploy AWS WAF with managed rules to protect applications behind your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Implement AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) in conjunction with your AWS Application Load Balancer to protect web applications from common web exploits and vulnerabilities. Utilize AWS WAF's managed rule sets to automatically block known threats, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and other common attacks, before they reach your application. Configure and customize WAF rules based on the specific needs of your application to ensure comprehensive protection. Regularly review and update the WAF rules to adapt to new threats and application changes, ensuring continuous security. Integrate WAF logging with AWS CloudWatch for monitoring and alerting on suspicious activity.

reference.name: Web Application Firewall, Web API Protection - AWS WAF

countermeasure.name: Enable access logging for your Application Load Balancer and integrate with CloudWatch and CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc: Enable access logging on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to capture detailed records of all incoming traffic. Integrate these logs with AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for suspicious activities and unauthorized access attempts. Set up automated alerts within CloudWatch to notify your team of any anomalies or potential security incidents. Regularly review the access logs to identify patterns or activities that may indicate security threats, and take proactive measures to address any identified risks. This control ensures that all traffic through the ALB is tracked and analyzed, enhancing the security and resilience of your application.

countermeasure.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that cross-zone load balancing is enabled on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to evenly distribute incoming traffic across all available zones within the region. This configuration enhances fault tolerance by preventing any single availability zone from becoming a bottleneck or single point of failure. It also improves resource efficiency by balancing the load across multiple zones, ensuring optimal performance and reducing the risk of overloading individual resources. Regularly verify that cross-zone load balancing is enabled and functioning as intended to maintain high availability and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing
